topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.1: Deploy the KVM Region Patch 13

body.bodydiv:
This patch is applicable for Denver, Tahoe, Memphis and Sacramento cloud topologies. It addresses the following issue in the KVM region:
Compute nodes (in this case, two) failed to recover while using Force Lock option during patch application process.
Logging of additional VIMs is now available.
Migrating halted instances from the compute nodes using Lock option caused issues. You can use the Horizon UI to see if the patch has been deployed. Select the regionkvm, then click Admin, then System, and Inventory. Click the Patches table for the TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0013.patch or use the CLI on the active KVM controller: sudo sw-patch query.
Prerequisites
The KVM region has already been configured and runnning.
You should have installed the following patches during the installation of the KVM Region
KVM Region Custom Patch ()
PCI Bus Patch ()
KVM Custom Patch 3 ()
KVM Custom Patch 4 ()
KVM Custom Patch 5 ()
KVM Custom Patch 6 ()
KVM Custom Patch 7 ()
KVM Custom Patch 8 ()
KVM Custom Patch 9 ()
KVM Custom Patch 10 ()
KVM Custom Patch 11 ()
KVM Custom Patch 12 ()
Start the patch download
To download the patch you need from the Software Updates and Licensing site, shown above:
Select the required patch file (e.g.) from the Downloads list and then click Download.
Un-tar the downladed files (compressed patch files with extension tar.gz and .tar) until the TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0013.patch and readme files are available.The tar files specified under Download filenameon the Software Licensing site are listed separately for HCG_2.0 and HCG_2.1 versions but when downloaded and extracted both the versions refer to a common tar file in the readme.
Check if the MD5 checksum verification file is extracted along with the patch file.
For validating the integrity of the downloaded file, you can run the MD5 checksum verification on the downloaded patch file and verify if the fingerprint of the file matches the version available on the server.
Install the patch
Patch the standby controller
SSH into active controller in the KVM region.
For example: controller-0 (active controller).
Create a directory for the patch:mkdir -p /tmp/patches
Copy the following patch file to the /tmp/patches directory:
TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0013.patch
Execute the following commands to upload the patch to the database: sudo sw-patch upload /tmp/patches/TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0013.patch
Execute the following commands to check if the patch is available for installation:sudo sw-patch query
For example:
Execute the following commands to apply the patch:sudo sw-patch apply TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0013 [This patch will be in "Partial-Apply" state]
Execute the following commands to check the current state of all the hosts:sudo sw-patch query-hostsYour host Reboot Required state will be Yes. For example:
Execute the following commands to source the openrc file:source /etc/nova/openrc or sudo -i
Execute the following command to patch and reboot the standby controller: system host-patch-reboot <controller-#>
For example if controller-1 is the standby controller and controller-0 is the active controller:system host-patch-reboot controller-1
Wait until the standby controller comes up after patching and is in Available state. This can be verified using system host-list command.
Execute the following command to switch the active controller from the specified controller: system host-swact controller-#
For example, if the active controller is controller-0:system host-swact controller-0
This command makes controller-1 the active controller and makes controller-0 the standby.
Exit the SSH session. Patch the new standby controller
Log onto the newly active controller and patch the standby controller.
SSH into the newly active controller.
For example: controller-1.
Execute the following command: source /etc/nova/openrc
Execute the following command to patch and reboot the standby controller: system host-patch-reboot <controller-#>
For example if controller-0 is the standby controller:system host-patch-reboot controller-0
Patch the compute nodes
Execute the following command to patch and reboot the compute-0: system host-patch-reboot compute-0
Execute the following command to patch and reboot compute-1: system host-patch-reboot compute-1
Repeat the previous step for each compute node that participates in the cloud.
Use the sudo sw-patch query-hosts command to check if all the nodes are unlocked and the patch 13 is in Applied state.
